poem:
**Transistor Radio**

Cycling over,  
  
the vast plain stretches—  

a parade of sky overhead.  

Mascara dreams,  

rebels with rock,  

riding rhythms,  

our wheels spin music,  

freedom's song.  

In the wind,  

we laugh with madness,  

each note a promise—  

a lifetime away from Baggy Trousers—  

youth rolling onward,  

eternally.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "‘I once said there’s no way I’ll still be playing Baggy Trousers at 30’: Suggs’s honest playlist The first song I fell in love withJudy Teen by Cockney Rebel. I’d seen Steve Harley on Top of the Pops and liked his look, with the mascara and bowler hat, like Alex from A Clockwork Orange. One day, me and my mates decided to cycle to Salisbury Plain. I had a transistor radio tied to the handlebars and". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
